svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: For production scenarios, use the Standard tier load balancer. Managed clusters create an Azure public Standard Load Balancer and fully qualified domain name with a static public IP for both the primary and secondary node types. You can also bring your own load balancer, which supports both Basic and Standard SKU load balancers.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Create additional, secondary node types for your workloads.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Use Standard SKU for production scenarios.
svcguide_recos.description: This level ensures the resource provider maintains cluster reliability. Standard cluster: A Standard SKU managed cluster provides the equivalent of durability level Silver. To achieve this using the standard cluster model, you will need to use 5 VMs (or more).

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Consider using Availability Zones for your Service Fabric clusters.
svcguide_recos.description: Service Fabric managed cluster supports deployments that span across multiple Availability Zones to provide zone resiliency. This configuration will ensure high-availability of the critical system services and your applications to protect from single-points-of-failure.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Consider using Azure API Management to expose and offload cross-cutting functionality for APIs hosted on the cluster.
svcguide_recos.description: API Management can integrate with Service Fabric directly.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: For stateful workload scenarios, consider using Reliable Services.
svcguide_recos.description: The Reliable Services model allows your services to stay up even in unreliable environments where your machines fail or hit network issues, or in cases where the services themselves encounter errors and crash or fail. For stateful services, your state is preserved even in the presence of network or other failures.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Ensure Network Security Groups (NSG) are configured to restrict traffic flow between subnets and node types. Ensure that the correct ports are opened for application deployment and workloads.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: When using the Service Fabric Secret Store to distribute secrets, use a separate data encipherment certificate to encrypt the values.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Deploy client certificates by adding them to Azure Key Vault and referencing the URI in your deployment.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Enable Microsoft Entra integration for your cluster to ensure users can access Service Fabric Explorer using their Microsoft Entra credentials. Don't distribute the cluster client certificates among users to access Explorer.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: For client authentication, use admin and read-only client certificates and/or Microsoft Entra authentication.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Create a process for monitoring the expiration date of client certificates.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Maintain separate clusters for development, staging, and production.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Ensure Network Security Groups (NSG) are configured to restrict traffic flow between subnets and node types.
svcguide_recos.description: For example, you may have an API Management instance (one subnet), a frontend subnet (exposing a website directly), and a backend subnet (accessible only to frontend).

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Deploy Key Vault certificates to Service Fabric cluster virtual machine scale sets.
svcguide_recos.description: Centralizing storage of application secrets in Azure Key Vault allows you to control their distribution. Key Vault greatly reduces the chances that secrets may be accidentally leaked.
key_phrases: Service Fabric cluster virtual machine scale sets

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Apply an Access Control List (ACL) to your client certificate for your Service Fabric cluster.
svcguide_recos.description: Using an ACL provides an additional level of authentication.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Use resource requests and limits to govern resource usage across the nodes in your cluster.
svcguide_recos.description: Enforcing resource limits helps ensure that one service doesn't consume too many resources and starve other services.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Encrypt Service Fabric package secret values.
svcguide_recos.description: Encryption on your secret values provides an additional level of security.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Include client certificates in Service Fabric applications.
svcguide_recos.description: Having your applications use client certificates for authentication provides opportunities for security at both the cluster and workload level.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Authenticate Service Fabric applications to Azure Resources using Managed Identity.
svcguide_recos.description: Using Managed Identity allow you to securely manage the credentials in your code for authenticating to various services without saving them locally on a developer workstation or in source control.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Follow Service Fabric best practices when hosting untrusted applications.
svcguide_recos.description: Following the best practices provides a security standard to follow.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Select appropriate VM SKU.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Use appropriate node type and size.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Use appropriate managed disk tier and size.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Avoid VM SKUs with temp disk offerings.
svcguide_recos.description: Service Fabric uses managed disks by default, so avoiding temp disk offerings ensures you don't pay for unneeded resources.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: If you need to select a certain VM SKU for capacity reasons and it happens to offer temp disk, consider using temporary disk support for your stateless workloads.
svcguide_recos.description: Make the most of the resources you're paying for. Using a temporary disk instead of a managed disk can reduce costs for stateless workloads.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Align SKU selection and managed disk size with workload requirements.
svcguide_recos.description: Matching your selection to your workload demands ensures you don't pay for unneeded resources.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Prepare a cluster monitoring solution.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Review the cluster health policies in the Service Fabric health model.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Prepare an application monitoring solution.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Review the application and service type health policies in the Service Fabric health model.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Prepare an infrastructure monitoring solution.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Design your cluster with build and release pipelines for continuous integration and deployment.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Use Application Insights to monitor your workloads.
svcguide_recos.description: Application Insights integrates with the Azure platform, including Service Fabric.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Create a process for monitoring the expiration date of client certificates.
svcguide_recos.description: For example, Key Vault offers a feature that sends an email when `x%` of the certificate's lifespan has elapsed.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: For pre-production clusters use Azure Chaos Studio to drill service disruption on a Virtual Machine Scale Set instance failure.
svcguide_recos.description: Practicing service disruption scenarios will help you understand what is at-risk in your infrastructure and how to best mitigate the issues if they arise.
key_phrases: Virtual Machine Scale Set instance failure

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Use Azure Monitor to monitor cluster and container infrastructure events.
svcguide_recos.description: Azure Monitor integrates well with the Azure platform, including Service Fabric.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Use Azure Pipelines for your continuous integration and deployment solution.
svcguide_recos.description: Azure Pipelines integrates well with the Azure platform, including Service Fabric.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Exclude the Service Fabric processes from Windows Defender to improve performance.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Select appropriate VM SKU.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Decide what programming model you will use for your services.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Use appropriate managed disk tier and size.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Exclude the Service Fabric processes from Windows Defender to improve performance.
svcguide_recos.description: By default, Windows Defender antivirus is installed on Windows Server 2016 and 2019. To reduce any performance impact and resource consumption overhead incurred by Windows Defender, and if your security policies allow you to exclude processes and paths for open-source software, you can exclude.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Consider using Autoscaling for your cluster.
svcguide_recos.description: Autoscaling gives great elasticity and enables addition or reduction of nodes on demand on a secondary node type. This automated and elastic behavior reduces the management overhead and potential business impact by monitoring and optimizing the amount of nodes servicing your workload.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Consider using Accelerated Networking.
svcguide_recos.description: Accelerated networking enables a high-performance path that bypasses the host from the data path, which reduces latency, jitter, and CPU utilization for the most demanding network workloads.

checklist_match.text: For Windows workloads use Accelerated Networking

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster architecture: Considering using encryption at host instead of Azure Disk Encryption (ADE).
svcguide_recos.description: This encryption method improves on ADE by supporting all OS types and images, including custom images, for your VMs by encrypting data in the Azure Storage service.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Review the Service Fabric programming models to decide what model would best suit your services.
svcguide_recos.description: Service Fabric supports several programming models. Each come with their own advantages and disadvantages. Knowing about the available programming models can help you make the best choices for designing your services.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Leverage loosely-coupled microservices for your workloads where appropriate.
svcguide_recos.description: Using microservices allows you to get the most out of Service Fabric's features.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Leverage event-driven architecture for your workloads where appropriate.
svcguide_recos.description: Using event-driven architecture allows you to get the most out of Service Fabric's features.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Workload architecture: Leverage background processing for your workloads where appropriate.
svcguide_recos.description: Using background processing allows you to get the most out of Service Fabric's features.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Service Fabric Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Cluster and workload architectures: Review the different ways you can scale your solution in Service Fabric.
svcguide_recos.description: You can use scaling to enable maximum resource utilization for your solution.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Use Active Geo-Replication to create a readable secondary in a different region.
svcguide_recos.description: If your primary database fails, perform a manual failover to the secondary database. Until you fail over, the secondary database remains read-only. Active geo-replication enables you to create readable replicas and manually failover to any replica if there is a datacenter outage or application upgrade. Up to four secondaries are supported in the same or different regions, and the secondaries can also be used for read-only access queries. The failover must be initiated manually by the application or the user. After failover, the new primary has a different connection end point.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Use Auto Failover Groups that can include one or multiple databases, typically used by the same application.
svcguide_recos.description: You can use the readable secondary databases to offload read-only query workloads. Because autofailover groups involve multiple databases, these databases must be configured on the primary server. Autofailover groups support replication of all databases in the group to only one secondary server or instance in a different region. Learn more about AutoFailover Groups and DR design.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Use a Zone-Redundant database.
svcguide_recos.description: By default, the cluster of nodes for the premium availability model is created in the same datacenter. With the introduction of Azure Availability Zones, SQL Database can place different replicas of the Business Critical database to different availability zones in the same region. To eliminate a single point of failure, the control ring is also duplicated across multiple zones as three gateway rings (GW). The routing to a specific gateway ring is controlled by Azure Traffic Manager (ATM). Because the zone redundant configuration in the Premium or Business Critical service tiers doesn't create extra database redundancy, you can enable it at no extra cost. Learn more about Zone-redundant databases.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Monitor your Azure SQL Database in near-real time to detect reliability incidents.
svcguide_recos.description: Use one of the available solutions to monitor SQL DB to detect potential reliability incidents early and make your databases more reliable. Choose a near real-time monitoring solution to quickly react to incidents. Reference Azure SQL Analytics for more information.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Implement Retry Logic.
svcguide_recos.description: Although Azure SQL Database is resilient when it concerns transitive infrastructure failures, these failures might affect your connectivity. When a transient error occurs while working with SQL Database, make sure your code can retry the call. For more information, reference how to implement retry logic.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Review the minimum TLS version.
svcguide_recos.description: Determine whether you have legacy applications that require older TLS or unencrypted connections. After you enforce a version of TLS, it's not possible to revert to the default. Review and configure the minimum TLS version for SQL Database connections via the Azure portal. If not, set the latest TLS version to the minimum.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Private endpoints and private link
svcguide_recos.description: Private endpoint connections enforce secure communication by enabling private connectivity to Azure SQL Database. You can use a private endpoint to secure connections and deny public network access by default. Azure Private Link for Azure SQL Database is a type of private endpoint recommended for Azure SQL Database.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Automated vulnerability assessments
svcguide_recos.description: Monitor for vulnerability assessment scan results and recommendations for how to remediate database vulnerabilities.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Advanced Threat Protection
svcguide_recos.description: Detect anomalous activities indicating unusual and potentially harmful attempts to access or exploit databases with Advanced Threat Protection for Azure SQL Database. Advanced Threat Protection integrates its alerts with Microsoft Defender for Cloud.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Microsoft Entra-only authentication
svcguide_recos.description: Consider disabling SQL-based authentication and allowing only on Microsoft Entra authentication.

checklist_match.description: For authenticated web application, use a well established Identity Provider like Azure AD or Azure AD B2C.  Leverage the application framework of your choice to integrate with this provider or use the App Service Authentication / Authorization feature.
checklist_match.text: Use an established Identity Provider for authentication

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Evaluate resource usage.
svcguide_recos.description: Evaluate the resource usage for all databases and determine if they've been sized and provisioned correctly. For non-production databases, consider scaling resources down as applicable. The DTUs or vCores for a database can be scaled on demand, for example, when running a load test or user acceptance test.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Fine-tune backup storage consumption
svcguide_recos.description: For vCore databases in Azure SQL Database, the storage consumed by each type of backup (full, differential, and log) is reported on the database monitoring pane as a separate metric. Backup storage consumption up to the maximum data size for a database is not charged. Excess backup storage consumption will depend on the workload and maximum size of the individual databases. For more information, see Backup storage consumption.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Evaluate Azure SQL Database Serverless.
svcguide_recos.description: Consider using Azure SQL Database serverless over the Provisioned Computing Tier. Serverless is a compute tier for single databases that automatically scales compute based on workload demand and bills for the amount of compute used per second. The serverless compute tier also automatically pauses databases during inactive periods when only storage is billed. It automatically resumes databases when activity returns. Azure SQL Database serverless isn't suited for all scenarios. If you have a database with unpredictable or bursty usage patterns interspersed with periods of low or idle usage, serverless is a solution that can help you optimize price-performance.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Consider reserved capacity for Azure SQL Database.
svcguide_recos.description: You can reduce compute costs associated with Azure SQL Database by using Reservation Discount. Once you've determined the total compute capacity and performance tier for Azure SQL databases in a region, you can use this information to reserve the capacity. The reservation can span one or three years. For more information, reference Save costs for resources with reserved capacity.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Elastic pools help you manage and scale multiple databases in Azure SQL Database
svcguide_recos.description: Azure SQL Database elastic pools are a simple, cost-effective solution for managing and scaling multiple databases that have varying and unpredictable usage demands. The databases in an elastic pool are on a single server and share a set number of resources at a set price. For more information, see Elastic pools for managing and scaling multiple databases.

svcguide_recos.description: Use one of the available solutions to monitor SQL DB to detect potential reliability incidents early and make your databases more reliable. Choose a near real-time monitoring solution to quickly react to incidents. Reference Azure SQL Analytics for more information.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Implement Retry Logic.
svcguide_recos.description: Although Azure SQL Database is resilient when it concerns transitive infrastructure failures, these failures might affect your connectivity. When a transient error occurs while working with SQL Database, make sure your code can retry the call. For more information, reference how to implement retry logic and Configurable retry logic in SqlClient introduction.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Diagnose and troubleshoot high CPU utilization.
svcguide_recos.description: Azure SQL Database provides built-in tools to identify the causes of high CPU usage and to optimize workload performance.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Understand blocking and deadlocking issues.
svcguide_recos.description: Blocking due to concurrency and terminated sessions due to deadlocks have different causes and outcomes.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Tune applications and databases for performance.
svcguide_recos.description: Tune your application and database to improve performance. Review best practices.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Review Azure portal utilization reporting and scale as appropriate.
svcguide_recos.description: After deployment, use built-in reporting in the Azure portal to regularly review peak and average database utilization and right-size up or down. You can easily scale single databases or elastic pools with no data loss and minimal downtime.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Review Performance Recommendations.
svcguide_recos.description: In the Intelligent Performance menu of the database page in the Azure portal, review and consider action on any of the Performance Recommendations and implement any index, schema, and parameterization issues.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Review Query Performance Insight.
svcguide_recos.description: Review Query Performance Insight for Azure SQL Database reports to identify top resource-consuming queries, long running queries, and more.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Configure Automatic tuning.
svcguide_recos.description: Provide peak performance and stable workloads through continuous performance tuning based on AI and machine learning. Consider using Azure Automation to configure email notifications for automatic tuning.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Evaluate potential use of in-memory database objects.
svcguide_recos.description: In-memory technologies enable you to improve performance of your application, and potentially reduce cost of your database. Consider designing some database objects in high-volume OLTP applications.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Leverage the Query Store.
svcguide_recos.description: Enabled by default in Azure SQL Database, the Query Store contains a wealth of query performance and resource consumption data, as well as advanced tuning features like Query Store hints and automatic plan correction. Review Query Store defaults in Azure SQL Database.

svcguide_recos.service: Azure Sql Database Well Architected Framework
svcguide_recos.text: Implement retry logic for transient errors.
svcguide_recos.description: Applications should include automatic transaction retry logic for transient errors including common connection errors. Leverage exponential retry interval logic.

svcguide_recos.text: Consider how your selected consistency level and replication mode impacts the Recovery point objective (RPO) in a region-wide outage.
Design your database account deployment so it spans at least two regions in Azure. Additionally, distribute your account across multiple availability zones when offered within your Azure region.

Evaluate the multi-region and single-region write strategies for your workload. For single-region write, design your workload to have at least a second read region for failover. Enable auto-failover for single-region write and multi-region read scenarios. For multi-region write, compare the tradeoffs in complexity and consistency against the advantages of writing to multiple regions. Review expectations during a regional outage for single-region and multi-region write accounts.
Enable service-managed failover for your account.
Design an end-to-end test of high availability for your application.

Walk through common backup processes including, but not limited to; point-in-time restore, recovering from accidental destructive operations, restoring deleted resources, and restoring to another region at a point-in-time. Configure account with continuous backup, choosing the appropriate retention period based on your business requirements.

Explore the designing resilient applications guide, review the default retry policy for the SDKs, and plan for custom handling for specific transient errors. These guides will give best practices to make application code resilient to transient errors.
Distribute your Azure Cosmos DB account across availability zones (when available).
svcguide_recos.description: Availability zones provide distinct power, networking, and cooling isolating hardware failures to a subset of your replicas. Azure Cosmos DB has multiple replicas that span across a single random availability zone when the availability zones feature isn't used. If the availability zone feature is used, replicas span across multiple availability zones.

svcguide_recos.text: Configure your Azure Cosmos DB account to span at least two regions.
svcguide_recos.description: Spanning multiple regions prevents your account from being entirely unavailable if there's an isolated region outage.

svcguide_recos.text: Enable service-managed failover for your account.
svcguide_recos.description: Service-managed failover allows Azure Cosmos DB to change the write region of a multiple-region account to preserve availability. This change occurs without user interaction. Understand the tradeoffs with service-managed failover and plan for forced failover if necessary. For more information, see building highly available applications.

svcguide_recos.text: Validate availability by testing failover manually with service-managed failover temporarily disabled.
svcguide_recos.description: Temporarily disabling service-manage failover allows you to validate the end-to-end high availability of your application with a manual failover started using a script or the Azure portal. Afterwards, you can reenable service-managed failover.

svcguide_recos.text: Reduce surface attack area by designing to use private endpoints in accordance with the security baseline for Azure Cosmos DB.
Create roles, groups, and assignments for control-plane and data-plane access to your account per the principle of least-privilege access. Consider disabling key-based authentication.
Assess service-level compliance and certifications in the context of current global personal data requirements.
Encrypt data at-rest or in-motion using service-managed keys or customer-managed keys (CMKs).
Audit user access, security breaches, and resource operations with control plane logs..
Monitor data egress, data changes, usage, and latency with data plane metrics.
Implement, at a minimum, the data protection and identity management security baselines.
svcguide_recos.description: Go through the security baseline including identity management and data protection. Implement the recommendations to secure your Azure Cosmos DB account.

svcguide_recos.text: Disable public endpoints and use private endpoints whenever possible.
svcguide_recos.description: Avoid leaving unnecessary or unused public endpoints available for surface area attacks to your account.

checklist_match.description: Azure Storage by default has a public IP address and is Internet-reachable. Private endpoints allow to securely expose Azure Storage only to those Azure Compute resources that need access, thus eliminating exposure to the public Internet
checklist_match.text: Consider using private endpoints for Azure Storage

svcguide_recos.text: Use role-based access control to limit control-plane access to specific identities and groups and within the scope of well-defined assignments.
svcguide_recos.description: Use role-based access control to prevent unintended access to your account. Assign appropriate roles and permissions to users or applications accessing Azure Cosmos DB.

svcguide_recos.text: Create virtual network endpoints and rules to limit access to the account.
svcguide_recos.description: Implement virtual network service endpoints and firewall rules to restrict access to your Azure Cosmos DB account. Use network security groups (NSGs) to control inbound and outbound traffic to and from the Azure Cosmos DB resources. Limiting access to trusted networks and applying appropriate network security measures helps protect your data from unauthorized access.

svcguide_recos.text: Follow best software development practices for secure access to data.
svcguide_recos.description: Follow secure coding practices and perform secure code reviews when developing applications that interact with Azure Cosmos DB. Protect against common security vulnerabilities like injection attacks, cross-site scripting (XSS), or insecure direct object references (IDOR). Implement input validation, parameterized queries, and appropriate error handling for common HTTP status codes to prevent security risks.

checklist_match.description: Span Cosmos account across two or more regions with multi-region writes
checklist_match.text: Distribute your data globally

svcguide_recos.text: Monitor control-plane logs for breaches.
svcguide_recos.description: Monitoring helps you track access patterns and audit logs, ensuring that your database remains secure and compliant with relevant data protection regulations. Monitoring data-plane metrics can also help identify unfamiliar patterns that might reveal a security breach. For more information, see security checklist for Azure databases.

svcguide_recos.text: Enable Microsoft Defender for Azure Cosmos DB
svcguide_recos.description: Microsoft Defender detects attempts to exploit databases in your Azure Cosmos DB for NoSQL account. Defender detects potential SQL injections, suspicious access patterns, and other potential exploitation.

checklist_match.description: Leverage Microsoft Defender to learn about suspicious activity and misconfigurations.
checklist_match.text: Enable Microsoft Defender for all of your storage accounts

svcguide_recos.text: Design an indexing policy that's considers the operations and queries you commonly make in your workload.

Determine a partition key or set of partition keys which have a value  that has high cardinality and does not change. Use the existing guidance and best practices to help select an appropriate partition key. Also, consider your indexing policy when determining a partition key.

Select a throughput allocation schema that's appropriate for your workload. Review the benefits of standard and autoscale throughput distributed at the database or container level. Also, consider serverless when appropriate. Review your workload's traffic patterns in the context of selecting a throughput allocation scheme.
Consider consistency levels as they relate to your workload. Also, consider if client sessions should alter the default consistency level.
Calculate the expected overall data storage for your workload. The size of items and indexes all influence your data storage cost. Calcuate the impact of replication and backup on storage costs.
Create a strategy to automatically remove older items that are no longer used or necessary. If required, export these items to a lower-cost storage solution before they are removed.
Evaluate your most common queries that minimize cross-partition lookups. Use this information to inform the process of selecting a partition key or customizing an indexing policy.
Monitor RU/s utilization and patterns.
svcguide_recos.description: Use metrics to monitor RU consumption from the very beginning of your solution. Use queries and other data research techniques to find antipatterns in your application code.

svcguide_recos.text: Customize your indexing policy to map to your workload.
svcguide_recos.description: The default indexing policy indexes all paths in an item, and this policy can have significant impacts to RU consumption and costs. Use an indexing policy designed based on only the paths that you need to index for your common queries. For write-heavy workloads, disable automatic indexing of columns not used in queries.

svcguide_recos.text: Select partition key\[s\] that are ideal for your workload.
svcguide_recos.description: The partition key\[s\] should distribute throughput consumption and data storage evenly across logical partitions. The selection should also minimize the number of unbounded cross-partition queries. Avoid hot partitions that receive a disproportionate amount of traffic, as unbalance partitions can increase throughput costs and transient errors. Use the most common search queries to determine potential partition key\[s\] that likely executes only single-partition or bounded cross-partition queries.

svcguide_recos.text: Use serverless or provisioned throughput, manual provisioning or autoscale, at the database or container level when appropriate for your workload.
svcguide_recos.description: Compare the provisioned throughput types and select the appropriate option for your workload. Generally, smaller and dev/test workloads might benefit from serverless throughput or manual shared throughput at the database level. Larger, mission-critical workloads might benefit from provisioned throughput assigned at the container level.

svcguide_recos.text: Configure the default consistency level for your application. When appropriate, downgrade the default consistency level in client sessions.
svcguide_recos.description: You might not always need to change the standard default consistency level or override it in client sessions. Consider the higher costs associated with reads at stronger consistency levels.

svcguide_recos.text: For dev/test workloads, use the Azure Cosmos DB emulator.
svcguide_recos.description: The Azure Cosmos DB emulator is an option for dev/test and continuous integration that can save on the costs of these common workloads for your development team. The emulator is also available as a Docker container image.

svcguide_recos.text: Use transactional batch operations
svcguide_recos.description: Design partitions to take advantage of transactional batch operations within a logical partition key for inserting. Use batch operations in client-side SDKS for inserting, updating, or deleting multiple documents in a single transaction request. This step can reduce the number of individual requests and can eventually lead to better throughput efficiency.

svcguide_recos.text: Use projection to reduce throughput costs of large query result sets.
svcguide_recos.description: Author queries to only project the minimal number of fields required from a result set. If calculations on fields are necessary, evaluate the throughput cost of performing those calculations server-side versus client-side.

svcguide_recos.text: Avoid using unbounded cross-partition queries.
svcguide_recos.description: Evaluate and author queries to ensure they search within a single logical partition whenever possible. Use query filters to control which logical partitions the query targets. If a query must search across logical partitions, bound the query to only search a subset of logical partitions instead of a full scan.

svcguide_recos.text: Implement time-to-live (TTL) to remove unused items.
svcguide_recos.description: Use TTL to automatically delete data that's no longer needed. Manage storage costs by removing expired or obsolete data. If necessary, export the expired data to a lower-cost storage solution.

svcguide_recos.text: Consider an analytical store for heavy aggregations.
svcguide_recos.description: Azure Cosmos DB analytical store automatically syncs your data to a separate column store to optimize for large aggregations, reporting, and analytical queries.

svcguide_recos.text: Draft a log and metrics monitoring strategy to differentiate between different workloads, flag exceptional scenarios, track patterns in exceptions/errors, and track host machine performance.
Design large workloads to use bulk operations whenever possible.
Define multiple alerts to monitor throttling, analyze throughput allocation, and track the size of your data.
Design a monitoring strategy for availability of your solution across regions.
Create and enforce best practices for automating the deployment of your Azure Cosmos DB for NoSQL account and resources.
Plan expected metric thresholds based on partition and index design. Ensure that there's a plan to monitor those metrics to determine how close they are to the planned thresholds.
Ensure application developers are using the latest version of the developer SDK.
svcguide_recos.description: Each Azure Cosmos DB for NoSQL SDK has a minimum recommended version. For more information, see .NET SDK and Java SDK.

svcguide_recos.text: Create identifiers in the client application to differentiate workloads.
svcguide_recos.description: Consider flags, such as the user-agent suffix, to identify what workload each log entry or metric should be associated with.

svcguide_recos.text: Capture supplemental diagnostics using the developer SDK.
svcguide_recos.description: Use the diagnostics injection techniques for each SDK to add supplemental information about the workload alongside default metrics and logs. For more information, see .NET SDK and Java SDK.

svcguide_recos.text: Create alerts associated with host machine resources.
svcguide_recos.description: Connectivity and availability issues might occur due to client-side host machine issues. Monitor resources such as CPU, memory, and storage on host machines with client applications using the Azure Cosmos DB for NoSQL SDKs.

checklist_match.text: Configure alerts on the most critical metrics

svcguide_recos.text: Use the bulk features of client SDKs for large operations.
svcguide_recos.description: Scenarios that require a high degree of throughput benefit from using the bulk feature of the SDK. The bulk feature automatically manages and batches operations to maximize throughput.

svcguide_recos.text: Create alerts for throughput throttling.
svcguide_recos.description: Use alerts to track throughput throttling beyond expected thresholds. Over time, review and adjust alerts as you learn more about your workload in relation to Azure Cosmos DB. The Normalized RU Consumption metric is a metric that measures the percentage utilization of provisioned throughput on a database or container. If this metric is consistently at 100%, requests likely return a transient error.

checklist_match.text: Configure alerts on the most critical metrics

svcguide_recos.text: Track query performance using metrics.
svcguide_recos.description: Use metrics to track the performance of your top queries over time. Evaluate if there are efficiencies to be found by updating th indexing policy or changing queries. If query performance is poor, troubleshoot performance and apply query best practices. For more information, see query performance tips.

svcguide_recos.text: Use templates to automatically deploy account resources.
svcguide_recos.description: Consider Azure Resource Manager, Bicep, or Terraform templates to automate the deployment of your account and subsequent resources. Ensure that your team is using the same templates to deploy to other nonproduction environments.

svcguide_recos.text: Track key metrics to identify common problems in your workload.
svcguide_recos.description: Use specific metrics to find common problems in your workload including, but not limited to; RU utilization, RU utilization by partition, throttling, and request volumes by type. For more information, see monitor data reference.

svcguide_recos.text: Define a performance baseline for your application. Measure how many concurrent users and transactions you might need to handle. Consider workload characteristics such as your average user flow, common operations, and spikes in usage.

Research your most common and most complex queries. Identify queries that use multiple lookups, joins, or aggregates. Consider these queries in any design considerations for the partition key or indexing policy.
For the most common queries, determine the number of results you expect per page. This number will help formalize a buffered item count for prefetched results.
Research your target users. Determine which Azure regions are closest to them.
